review:
Thumbs up! There are some flaws, but this is a pretty good HOG (hidden object game). The plot is an extremely derivative mixture of Buffy the Vampire Slayer, Xena: Warrior Princess, They Live and a few others, but I still liked it better than the usual HOG plot of finding a missing relative. In any case, the plot of a HOG isnâ€™t what most people focus on. People are interested in the hidden object scenes and this game has a nice mix. The types of hidden object scenes include word list, fragmented object, silhouette, and placing items where they belong.

There is some pixel-hunting involved in the point and click adventure part, but most of the time itâ€™s pretty clear what you have to do. Itâ€™s important to remember that a solution may involve using a special item such as a potion or Xenaâ€™s chakram (throwing disc). The chakram isnâ€™t kept in your inventory, but has a separate icon next to the journal. There is an instant travel map for some of the game, but not for the whole game. Iâ€™m not sure exactly when I got the map, because the map doesnâ€™t have a separate icon. You need to look at the journal to see it. 

I thought the achievements were pretty reasonable. There are the standard HOG ones for not skipping mini-games or for not using hints in hidden object scenes, but you donâ€™t have to play on the hardest difficulty level. You can play on any difficulty you want and still get all the achievements. The only one that might be missed is True Historian, but there are guides available. The achievements for talking to the psychologist are right at the beginning, so you donâ€™t have to play the whole game again to get them.

This game was originally released in 2013 and there are some glitches running it under Windows 10. Sometimes the cursor didnâ€™t move to the bottom of the screen, but toggling the custom cursor on and off in the options menu seemed to help. The game did crash and I had to restart my computer, but when I restarted the game, I returned to the same scene. I didnâ€™t lose any progress, so the crash wasnâ€™t totally game-breaking. 

This game is a standard edition, not a collectorâ€™s edition, so there arenâ€™t any extra features like a bonus chapter, replaying mini-games, or the option to save the music. Thatâ€™s a shame since I liked the music. The artwork is pretty good too. I think that this could have been the start of a good series, but they never made a sequel.

review:
Hot babes in latex saving universe from ancient evil in a dumb story, typical for B class movies. Actually, why not? Not a revelation, but fun enough to entertain you. 

Overall impression - very good. Very beautiful visuals and highly detailed locations. Good set of puzzles and mini-games. Probably I should mention that it is more a point and click, rather than hidden object game. It also has rather easy achievements and of course - thicc cast.

review:

Not only this but you'd get items you need to progress just randomly that made no sense in-game: why did that keeper hold the other half of the blacksmith's mold? Overall, I cannot understand why this has "very positive" reviews on Steam, it's a really mediocre game.

review:
Undoubtedly among the best hidden object games I've played, which shouldn't be taken as particularly high praise given how closely Dark Angels: Masquerade of Shadows hews to genre conventions. It's all the same puzzles with the same art style and the same unnecessary vague horror themes, but the pace is relatively brisk and there's a decent amount of variety, even if half of what you're doing is finding weirdly distinct keys that correspond to locks that could be just as easily bypassed with the assortment of sharp and heavy implements lining your pockets.

I'm usually quick to skip the embarrassing story scenes in these games, but I was actually motivated to see what would happen next in this one. I mean, it's terrible, but at least it was amusingly terrible. Why are they stealing directly from They Live? Beats me! Just know that if you're expecting any of it to lead to an interesting conclusion, you are playing the wrong game.

review: It's a fun little hidden object game that is great for novices. The story is fairly basic, but it moves the game along. The art is nice, the music good, it basically all works. The game is nothing really special, but it does what a HoG should for the most part.  The game has settings to have hints which are really well done. It basically highlights the area, then the object you are missing. You can also skip puzzles if you get stuck.  Over all the puzzles are not to hard, but ya never know when you can over look something simple. Much better than going for a guide because you are stuck.  At the hardest level hints/skip is turned off.For fan's of this style game its right in the middle, does nothing great and nothing bad. It's just a short little Hog experience. I've played others that i liked a bit more but for a nice little diversion for an evening or two this does the job fairly well. Check my other reviews for other adventures i really enjoyed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052388186', 'num_games_owned': 240, 'num_reviews': 145, 'playtime_forever': 517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 517, 'last_played': 1594795771}
review:
I enjoyed this game very much.  The plot is beyond derivative-- you play as the daughter of a 90's vampire slayer who is part of a mystical sorority founded by a warrior-princess that wields a Chakram (seriously, I am not exaggerating) and you have to go to Warehouse 13 (I am not making this up) to time-travel so you can undo what went wrong in the past.  And you have 3 super-powers: strength, x-ray vision and super-speed.

But for all that, or maybe because of all that, the game is great.  I have posted screen-shots of some of the HOG scenes and puzzles as I really found everything here very entertaining.   

The game did crash on me once, but when I re-loaded it, it went exactly back to the scene where it crashed so I didn't lose any data (or as Dr. Pulaski would say, daytuh) and it never crashed again.  All achievements are doable, though some of the puzzles are extremely challenging.  However, there is a video walkthrough in the Guides section if you get stuck.

Note: this game has the best music of any HOG that I have ever played, and I've now played 3 or 4.  Maybe 5.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068479644', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1595186113}
review:
Above average.
This game stole its inspiration from the very best: They live, Buffy the Vampire Slayer, Xena Warrior Princess, Vampire the Masquerade to name just a few. It's a fine mixture.
You're Kate, a chosen warrior who has to fight hidden dark ones in the modern world. There are other warrior women like you, but the just stand around in cool poses. It's almost a satyr at times.
The game is nicely drawn but a very short. The puzzles are alright, so are the hidden objects. Sometimes you have to look hard for little clues and sometime the object use doesn't make sense. Side note: you have a very sharp instrument with you, but you can't use it to cut or destroy things. The voiceover is very bad but the whole setting is kind of cool and it has its own theme song! 
I liked the game but it could have been better. Don't pay full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971145113', 'num_games_owned': 1308, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1577020851}
review:
[h1]The Story[/h1]
Kate has nightmares about the death of her mother when she was young, by a demon-like monster. Now she is an adult, and is seeing them again. It turns out that she has inherited the role of a Keeper, one of a group of catsuit-clad supermodels who fight the Dark Ones. As this is a HOG, she does it mostly by finding strange things to unlock chests and bags, and searching through peculiar piles of objects in search of miscellaneous unrelated items. A number of women throughout history were Keepers, Joan of Arc was one. So was Marilyn Monroe!

[h1]The Game[/h1]
Anyway, the game has a clear dividing line between the first and second halves. The first is slightly more original, but the second is completely standard for the genre. It has make-a-potion-from-ingredients and make-a-thing-in-a-forge mini puzzles, just like almost every hidden object game ever. Graphics-wise it is fairly average. It has a couple of songs, which is unusual. The game is pretty easy, apart from a couple of points which can cause trouble.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
The game is quite average in every way, but I am giving a thumbs-down because the second half is less interesting than the first and there are a few rough edges.

review:
#73 Dark Angels

So first off, it's a search game without so much search.  Its short, about 3-4 hours of game play, if that. The puzzles are just...off.  Ok, i'm a bit ahead of myself.  My general impression: this is not the best search and find puzzle game out there.  The story is mediocre, it sticks to the tropes of the genre.  You're a woman with a mysterious past/traumatic past that has nightmares of a dark event in the past.  Suddenly someone shows up and you suddenly have the most powerful object in history hidden in your home.  Now that you're a powerful, strong woman you have to save the town/world/family member from some dark and mysterious force.  Seriously, all these games have the same tropes right down to the idea that only women play these types of games because of  the casual nature of these games.  The search puzzles are easy, and mediocre at best.  I think there was only 6 or 7 of this type, and i finished them within a few minutes of starting them.  The actual puzzles are a nightmare.  Many give you no direction at all, forcing you to search the internet for the basic idea of the puzzle, and scratching your head when they're solved, many by accident.  One puzzle forces you to play a checkers style game.  The only way to get all the achievements is play the game twice, which, OMG, is a serious bore.  It has little replay value, if any.

Now, lets talk about the voice acting.  There isn't any.  Its like one woman is thrilled to death to be talking about the death of your mother.  You can literally feel the smile in her voice.  Was there no direction at all?  No one to say, "Ok, now be serious and morose."  Or is this the family of the game designers that were simply handed a script and told to have at it?  Granted, you can't be expected to have Emmy material acting here, but a little effort isn't too much to ask for.

This one is a no.
BTW: developers of this style of game, guys like to play these too.  Maybe a few that don't pander to the idea that only women can handle a simple and casual game.  You know,  Ron Burgundy these bad boys.  Give them meat.  Ok, i'll make it simple:  Make them harder.

3/10
8+, cuz' the actual puzzles will aggravate the hell out of smaller kids and will end up skipping them.
graphics and sound are middling.  Typical fare for this style of game.
final thought: bundle fodder, which is where this one came from.

review:
Dark Angels is rough around the edges but ultimately gets a passing grade on account of its production value. The graphics and music are nice, you get multiple dialogue options at points (no effect on the game, just for fun), the story is suitably silly, the HOPs are quite decent and overall it offers a nice variety of gameplay elements. Even some of the dumber puzzles are still amusing, the one where you pick 4 items and press play to see how the story plays it is rather amusing.

That said, there's certainly room for criticism. A couple of the puzzles are quite tedious so i skipped them, interactive objects require slightly too much accuracy at times, the voice acting is terrible (though this also cracked me up a few times) and sometimes it's hard to figure out what to do next because the game doesn't explain how you can use the chakram/potions and some of the solutions are confusing. For instance, you have to feed your cat and you find food and a bowl. But it turns out the bowl is used later on and you have to put the food in another bowl. A couple of times i did need help to progress. Also, a few items are labelled incorrectly. You get a "chest key" but it opens a drawer, for instance. These kind of things would have been easy to fix before release.

Dark Angels is still fun enough to recommend. It takes 3 hours to complete so it's definitely worth a few euros.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201178622', 'num_games_owned': 1357, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1553406381}
review:
Artifex Mundi has often been heralded as the masters of Hidden Object games. Now that the company is no longer creating HOGs, fans of the genre are left searching for alternatives.

This entry by Skywind Games under the Alawar banner is one which can soothe that itch remarkably well.

Dark Angels: Masquerade of Shadows introduces a world where a group of women fight monsters in the shadows - monsters which seek to control humanity while disguised as regular people. The graphics are outstanding for a 2013 HOG title, and there are very few bugs to run into despite the game's age. A simple "combat" system is included, where you can use your chakram to defeat foes and solve puzzles.

The music for this game is absolutely outstanding, with the intro theme (which is peppered throughout the game) performed by a talented vocalist who, sadly, isn't listed in the credits.  A lot of the commentary is humorous, although the voice actress for the main character, Kate (because HOG heroes tend to be named Kate) tends to sound almost hysterical in many scenes. This is just a bit of overacting, however, and doesn't hurt the game overall.

If anything drags this game down, it's the Act II/IV plot. Act 1 is all about learning Kate's destiny and is extraordinarily done, but the second Act gets into the cliche of time travel. Act III makes up for this pretty well, only to return to the time theme in the brief fourth and final Act. Overall, the game has a pretty rich backstory and a lot to offer, so I can forgive this dip into the bargain plot bin for the way they tried to work it in. A professional writer will always get picky about this sort of thing, so I won't push my judgement too far (the same can go for temporally inaccurate objects in historical HOG scenes).


Overall, this almost immediately became a favourite in my HOG library, and I'm tempted to write a few short stories based on the lore. Dark Angels sadly has yet to gain a sequel, but at only $4 USD at regular price, it's a title no self-respecting HOG fan should pass up - doubly so if it's on sale! And if you enjoy this game, please be sure to write Alawar and let them know you want to see this become a series.

Pro:
+ The Main character is really likeable and I love the start of the game where you can see a part of her job.
+ Music. I just love the song and the overall music in the game.
+ The art is just beautiful and it improves the mood to play the game.
+ Achievments! I am one of those people that love to collect them.
+ Story: The story is something diffrent than most other games I have played before. But there is also a small critic to it.

[spoiler] Your start with a short insight what happend in your past and get a look what your work is like (which is one of the parts I love the most) Than you meet your enemies and escape and find your mates and try to join them passing a few "tests". After that i thought I would fight with them but the story takes a sudden turn. Suddenly most of the watchers are gone and you have to fight the enemies with a few left. Good idea but rushed. You are in the past which was nice but also way to short. I would rather have a multiple part story game (even pay 2-3 times) than one rushed story[/spoiler]
- Potions. It was a nice idea which fits perfectly with the story, but it was a little underwhelmed in my opinion. Not that many actions like above i would have prefered it if there where more situations whre they were used.

-Puzzles: A lot are nice and wellmade. Easy but not to easy. But the last puzzle brought it to the neutral point. It is somehow random and after mulitple tries i suddenly won. I dont really like random puzzles that much.

review:
[b][u]Game Information[/u][/b]

"Dark Angels: Masquerade of Shadows" is a Hidden Object Puzzle Adventure game. The game was developed by Skywind Games and published by Alawar Stargaze.

[b][u]The Game Review[/u][/b]

Game Visuals

I want to mention that the visuals in the game are nicely done. The visuals can be adjusted in the game's option menu.

Game Audio

I want to mention that audio for the game is well done. Even though the audio is somewhat simplistic and repetitive. The audio can be adjusted in the game's option menu as well.

Gameplay

There are three different game difficulty modes to choose from: Amateur; Casual and Expert.

The notebook keeps track of the progression in the game. Such as story events and clues.

There is an interactive map in the game. It allows the player to fast travel between each location quickly without having the need to constantly backtrack. It also indicates that there are a variety of tasks that can be completed at various locations within the game. The interactive map is not automatically given at the start of the game.

There is no padlock feature that is available to lock the inventory panel in place to make it stationary. The inventory panel does slide up when it is being moused over.

The hidden object scenes consist of the following: Shadow items; Fragmented items; Traditional word list and Placing items back. Some of these hidden object scenes may require a little or no interaction.

The puzzles are fairly easy to solve without having the need to skip any of them.

There are thirty different achievements that can be unlocked from playing the game. Most of these achievements do come with some requirements that need to be completed before they can be unlocked.

Miscellaneous

There are six different trading cards to collect. Only three of those trading cards are given out by the game. There are several ways to get the rest of the trading cards: Purchased from the Steam's Community Market; Trade with friends; Booster Packs and its Booster Pack Creator.

Final thoughts: I have found the game enjoyable to certain extent. The replay value for the game is low. I would recommend this game, but not at the game's full price value.

[h1]Short version: 71%[/h1]
Dark Angles has an interesting balance for a hidden object game. Its first half excels in storytelling but lacks in interesting gameplay mechanics, whereas the second half does the exact opposite. 

[h1]Long version:[/h1]
An all-female quasi-mystical group of warriors fighting the good fight against the ancient forces of evil is a favoured topic in modern action fantasy settings. Dark Angels: Masquerade falls into this line, following the adventures of the newest initiate to an order of leather-clad women, who has to take her motherâ€™s mystical chakram to combat a bunch of clandestine monsters. Said monsters not only invaded every levels of society, but also manage to muster an attack against our heroes on more than one time planes.

From this setup, one would expect some third-person action/adventure, maybe a hack & slash, but Dark Angels is a humble hidden object game. Granted, a very action-packed one for its genre.
Still, a HOG has to include the usual elements, so after the climactic attack, the story mostly takes a backseat to add most of the hidden object scenes and some traditional puzzles expected by its audience. Ironically, this is probably the gameâ€™s biggest issue, since the premise does not really fit the adventure game nature of HOGs. It should not keep away any HOG player though, especially if they like awesome soundtracks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028216179', 'num_games_owned': 2423, 'num_reviews': 159, 'playtime_forever': 240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1496126128}
review:
[i]Dark Angels: Masquerade of Shadows[/i] is a hidden object adventure game that focuses on Kate Evans, a young modern day woman who becomes entangled in a world of demons and freedom fighters. Itâ€™s a fun game filled with action, fun puzzles and hidden object scenes, it also has great music and visuals. While itâ€™s certainly not a perfect game having an outlandish plot, some irritating puzzles and audio issues, for the price tag I enjoyed playing it and was able to look past its flaws. Though it may not be the best hidden object game on the market itâ€™s still a good gaming experience.
 
Kate is a young fashion designer haunted by the memories of her motherâ€™s death though she soon finds out the beings responsible for this murder are now after her. Her mother was part of a secret organization that fights demons, one that dates back hundreds of years and has notable members like Jeanne dâ€™Arc and, I kid you not, Marilyn Monroe. Things get even more complicated as the dark forces have built a time machine and use it to erase the organization from existence, prompting Kate and a few survivors to commandeer it and go back in time themselves.
 
The plot is just all over the place and while Iâ€™ve played hidden object games with weaker storylines, this one could have been better. Itâ€™s completely unrealistic that Kate went from a fashion designer worrying about clothing one moment and then becomes the saviour of an entire guild of demon hunters. She has little to no training but that doesnâ€™t stop her from wielding her weapon like a pro, granted itâ€™s mainly due to the player controlling her. While I know she is the main character and thus has to be the hero, it sort of hurts the validity of the game that such a novice outshines women who have much more experience.
 
This is a point-and-click hidden object game so all you need is a mouse to play. You can interact with people and objects, collecting useful ones along the way. Items are stored in your inventory and some can be combined to make a new item though the game does this automatically for you. One note about the inventory is that you can lock it in place so it always minimizes when not in use, this is a pet peeve of mine. You only have a fast travel map when youâ€™re time traveling though you donâ€™t really need one in the present day since there isnâ€™t much backtracking involved. I enjoyed the variety of hidden object puzzles, while there are your basic list of items to find there are also ones where youâ€™re given a shadow of an item and have to find in a scene as well as other types. While there is also a nice variety of puzzles, some are rather frustrating and some are often just pointless. Putting a puzzle on the side of a truck is pretty silly.
 
This game is riddled with annoying item fetch-quests for problems that could be solved in a much easier way. One example would be when Kate has to find a shard of glass despite having a very sharp weapon always on hand. Another odd feature is that of dialogue choice, while I do think this can be fun it really has no effect whatsoever on the gameplay or story at all, thus proving to be pointless. Kate can also use special potions to grant her super strength, special sight and slow down time. An interesting feature but a needless add -on. Also, the only way to get these potions is to find figurines and add them to what seems to be a checker board that Kate somehow always carries around. Adding a new figure grants Kate a potion which is always conveniently the exact one sheâ€™ll need for her next problem.
 
On the plus side, this game has very nice graphics with attractive character models and good animation. The colors are vibrant and nothing is too dark or hard to see. This game also has its own theme song which sounds beautiful. The lyrics are touching and the melody is very soothing but very catchy. Iâ€™ve never played a hidden object game that had its own song, I actually sat through the credits a few times just to hear the full song. Sadly, the rest of the gameâ€™s audio is hit or miss. While the background music and sound effects are fine, the voice acting is the issue. Itâ€™s fully voice-acted but some actors arenâ€™t very good and Kate herself sometimes overacts her lines. Also, there are some problems with audio quality, as some characters sound louder than others.
 
While it might seem like Iâ€™m picking apart [i]Dark Angels: Masquerade of Shadows[/i], in the end I really enjoyed playing it. It was fun and had great hidden object scenes, plus I did like Kate for the most part as a main character though they could have fleshed her out more. The good part about this game is that itâ€™s cheap so even if itâ€™s not the best hidden object game, for its price point itâ€™s a really good one. The game also has Steam trading cards and achievements which are not too hard to collect. I recommend this game to fans of the genre, itâ€™s a good game for a good price.

[*][b]A good game to buy.[/b]
[*]Only buy if on sale.
[*]Mediocre.
[*]Avoid at all costs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026806776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 302, 'playtime_forever': 193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1495816827}
review:
When I started playing [i]Dark Angels: Masquerade of Shadows[/i] I was certain that I would give it a thumbs up.  The graphics are top-notch for the genre, and the music exceeds anything I would expect to hear in a HOG. The plot, though an absurd mash-up of [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/15100/Assassins_Creed_Directors_Cut_Edition/]Assassin's Creed[/url] and [url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0096256/]They Live[/url] with ridiculous gaping plot holes, is still rather fun.  The cutscenes are unusually long and well done.  The whole thing seems carefully polished.

However, for all the prettiness of it, I don't think I have ever sworn in frustration at a HOG so many times as I did at [i]Masquerade of Shadows[/i].  The more I played, the more I hated it.

The issue that kept infuriating me, over and over, relates to the nature of the progress barriers.  That's how the overworld in a HOG functions, of course -- an array of progress barriers, functionally doors in disguise, requiring a variety of objects that act as keys, which you must obtain by finding them, solving puzzles or playing minigames.  Here, however, the progress barriers were all so [b]stupid[/b] and [b]arbitrary![/b]  At one point, for instance, my character needs to open a container, but it is tied shut with a piece of string.  She is carrying no less than [b]three[/b] sharp objects, but she can't cut the string until she finds a piece of broken glass, because apparently none of the much better cutting implements [i]that she's already carrying[/i] will do!

At another point, there's an object I want lying in the dirt.  It's right there.  I can see it.  But my character won't pick it up until I find a glove for her, because she doesn't want to get her hand dirty.

My constant refrain to this game was "Just ^&#*ing [b]do it[/b], already!  What's stopping you???"  

I click on a cart, and the character helpfully tells me that she could push the cart.  "I [b]know[/b] you can push the cart," I scream. "I want you to do it!  Stop telling me that you can do it, and just do it!  What is your problem???  Is it that wheel chock?  It's a single little block of wood!  Just kick it out of the way like a normal person!  Do you really need a corkscrew and an electric toothbrush just to remove a #%^$ing wheel chock???"

Over and over, the biggest challenge in the game is figuring out precisely what dumb object your character wants in order to overcome some silly problem that should be trivial to handle in any number of ways.  Even though progress barriers like these are an inherent element of the game, the ridiculously contrived nature of those barriers, along with the sole means of passing them, just overwhelmed my ability to suspend disbelief.

It doesn't help that the means of giving you the "keys" is often just as baldly contrived as the problems that require them.  At least a half-dozen times in the game, something that you achieve will result in a character saying some form of "It's dangerous to go alone. Take this," and then handing you some bizarre object that no sane person would possibly expect you to need, but that is, of course, exactly what you need to pass another barrier.  As if that wasn't enough, you also drag around a magic checkerboard whose role is to dole out key items at exactly the time you need them and not before.

I don't expect realism from a HOG, but please, at least work with me a little!  Make the impediments to progress plausible!  Ensure that the expected means of solving those problems is the most logical one!  Present key objects in a way that isn't blatantly handing them to me!

Add a few localization errors and a touchy UI just to add spice to an already infuriating stew.  I've never before given the thumbs down to a HOG that is, on the surface, so technically meritorious, but, similarly, I've never had such an unpleasant time playing one, either.

review:
Obviously some effort gone into the music on this one so that was quite nice. 

The story is just really really stupid but nevertheless manages to remain engaging. The HOGs are varied between traditional shopping lists, find the pieces and there's even a reverse HOG in there somewhere as well as bunches of pointing and clicking that all actually feels connected to the story. I wasn't a fan of the potion gimmick, I felt it was poorly done and could have been so much better.

If you like achievement hunting then it's probably worth knowing you can get all bar one achievement in one playthrough, the one missing one is due to choices you make during the intro so you can pick up the alternate route in just a couple of minutes.

Overall it was a well put together, fun example of this genre. Nothing too taxing in there, so probably not ideal if you're looking for a challenge.

I can't quite leave without commenting on the story though, more because it made me laugh than er... because it needs commenting on.
[spoiler]The weird girl power vs evil men monsters theme.[/spoiler]
[spoiler]The fact that although you are the noobiest of the order of supergirls the others prefer to sit around looking mysterious.[/spoiler]
[spoiler]That moment when everything is going wrong and blondie will still only turn to you and talk about manicures.[/spoiler]
[spoiler]Why nobody other than your character seems at all concerned about you all being wiped out.[/spoiler]
[spoiler]I just don't understand why, at the point where they have thrown you back in time they actively chose to leave you with other supergirls to play with, who then do absolutely nothing to help the situation other than hangout in the super secret den! They could have isolated you, only you made it back, the ones there are all dead etc and then you doing everything would have made sense but nooo.[/spoiler]

review:

I thought they could have done a little more with this idea. They just dont use it enough. 

The music and sound effects are very solid. I really liked the soundtrack. I really liked the game overall. Just a few other nit picks. Your character is a women. No big deal their. The part that is a bummer is no bonus chapter. So its the main game only. However overall the game is very fun and I did finish it.

review:
Fashion, time machine, beautiful art and music, this game is a rare gem. The story is really interesting to the point that I couldn't close the game and played it for 5 hours straight to the end. The main character is an orphan girl who was a fashion designer, living in a modern apartment with a cute kitty. Her life isn't calm and normal though as she experienced something in her childhood, witnessing her mother's death which leads her to see a psychologist, and in that very day, suddenly her life turned upside down and the fun begins. [spoiler]I loved her high heels when she was escaping the villains[/spoiler]
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=880466611

At first, I thought the game doesn't have a map, which we do have a little bit of backtracking, but in the middle of the game, you'll be provided with a map and fast traveling too.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=880471235

Pro:
+Amazing graphics and characters design.
+Interesting story which will keep you engaged.
+Good music especially after traveling.
+Voice acting is OK, but the main character does sound funny and overreacting sometimes.
+Very useful journal with a nice design.
+Fast travel map.
+Easy achievements.
+Steam achievements.

Cons:
-Some of the puzzles are very very annoying, one of them took me 20 minutes to solve, and the other for almost half an hour! 
-Few hidden objects scenes.

I bought it in a bundle and it was a good deal, I really recommend this game for any hidden object lover, it is very cheap and a must-have.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969267147', 'num_games_owned': 7582, 'num_reviews': 572, 'playtime_forever': 516, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 516, 'last_played': 1487049970}
review:
There's a lot to like about casual point-and-click adventure: diverse locales, exciting story, great graphics, and a few fun hidden-object scenes, as well as easy mini-games. There's even a cheesy â€œgothâ€ theme song. Fans of the genre would enjoy this.

There are some stand-out elements. First of all, it's, like, the girliest of the girliest of themes. We already know these games target a female audience, but having you play as a stunning fashion designer is laying it on a bit thick... hope you enjoy arranging fashion collections and refusing to get dirty. And obviously all the women-warrior-heroes look like supermodels. There are also some nice ideas for mechanics involving combat and magic, which unfortunately are barely used.

There are two problems: one is that it's too short and easy. The other is that there's a major production blunder for the English voice acting. It's usually fine, but once in a while the protagonist's voice is replaced with this bizarre shrill [i]other[/i] voice that I imagine was a placeholder during development. Either they forget to replace those audio clips, or they just didn't finish the production. It ends up being quite jarring, but also funny.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006413390', 'num_games_owned': 3172, 'num_reviews': 214, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1535775665}
review:
This is a point and click adventure game with hidden object and puzzle minigames featuring a female protagonist Kate Evans, a modern day fashion designer who suffer from nightmares of her mother's death from a monster years earlier. One day, the same monsters which haunted her and could take on human forms start to appear to try to kill her, which lead Kate to discover her place in a secret order of female warriors dedicated to fighting an ancient evil for centuries. After joining the order, Kate discovers some of her latent supernatural abilities and also the existence of a time machine, leading Kate into a journey to the middle ages to confront the evil monsters and to save her mother from death.

All puzzle and hidden object minigames are easy to complete and forgiving for casual players. Recommended when at discount or in bundle offer as it takes less than 10 hours to finish. Overall, recommended for fans who enjoy casual adventure games with puzzle/hidden object minigames, great soundtracks and achievements that are easy to obtain.
